Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar A couple of years ago I started using Twitter, and one of the things that really charmed me about Twitter is that people would wake up in the morning and they would say, "Good morning!" which I thought, I'm a Canadian, so I was a little bit, I liked that politeness. And so, I'm also a giant nerd, and so I wrote a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!" And then I asked myself my favorite question, "What would that look like?" Well, as it turns out, I think it would look something like this. Right, so we'd see this wave of people saying, "Good morning!" across the world as they wake up. Now the green people, these are people that wake up at around 8 o'clock in the morning, Who wakes up at 8 o'clock or says, "Good morning!" at 8? And the orange people, they say, "Good morning!" around 9. And the red people, they say, "Good morning!" around 10. Yeah, more at 10's than, more at 10's than 8's. And actually if you look at this map, we can learn a little bit about how people wake up in different parts of the world. People on the West Coast, for example, they wake up a little bit later than those people on the East Coast. But that's not all that people say on Twitter, right? We also get these really important tweets, like, "I just landed in Orlando!! [plane sign, plane sign]" Or, or, "I just landed in Texas [exclamation point]!" Or "I just landed in Honduras!" These lists, they go on and on and on, all these people, right? So, on the outside, these people are just telling us something about how they're traveling. But we know the truth, don't we? These people are show-offs! They are showing off that they're in Cape Town and I'm not. So I thought, how can we take this vanity and turn it into utility? So using a similar approach that I did with "Good morning," I mapped all those people's trips because I know where they're landing, they just told me, and I know where they live because they share that information on their Twitter profile. So what I'm able to do with 36 hours of Twitter is create a model of how people are traveling around the world during that 36 hours. And this is kind of a prototype because I think if we listen to everybody on Twitter and Facebook and the rest of our social media, we'd actually get a pretty clear picture of how people are traveling from one place to the other, which is actually turns out to be a very useful thing for scientists, particularly those who are studying how disease is spread. So, I work upstairs in the New York Times, and for the last two years, we've been working on a project called, "Cascade," which in some ways is kind of similar to this one. But instead of modeling how people move, we're modeling how people talk. We're looking at what does a discussion look like. Well, here's an example. This is a discussion around an article called, "The Island Where People Forget to Die". It's about an island in Greece where people live a really, really, really, really, really, really long time. And what we're seeing here is we're seeing a conversation that's stemming from that first tweet down in the bottom, left-hand corner. So we get to see the scope of this conversation over about 9 hours right now, we're going to creep up to 12 hours here in a second. But, we can also see what that conversation looks like in three dimensions. And that three-dimensional view is actually much more useful for us. As humans, we are really used to things that are structured as three dimensions. So, we can look at those little off-shoots of conversation, we can find out what exactly happened. And this is an interactive, exploratory tool so we can go through every step in the conversation. We can look at who the people were, what they said, how old they are, where they live, who follows them, and so on, and so on, and so on. So, the Times creates about 6,500 pieces of content every month, and we can model every single one of the conversations that happen around them. And they look somewhat different. Depending on the story and depending on how fast people are talking about it and how far the conversation spreads, these structures, which I call these conversational architectures, end up looking different. So, these projects that I've shown you, I think they all involve the same thing: we can take small pieces of data and by putting them together, we can generate more value, we can do more exciting things with them. But so far we've only talked about Twitter, right? And Twitter isn't all the data. We learned a moment ago that there is tons and tons, tons more data out there. And specifically, I want you to think about one type of data because all of you guys, everybody in this audience, we, we, me as well, are data-making machines. We are producing data all the time. Every single one of us, we're producing data. Somebody else, though, is storing that data. Usually we put our trust into companies to store that data, but what I want to suggest here is that rather than putting our trust in companies to store that data, we should put the trust in ourselves because we actually own that data. Right, that is something we should remember. Everything that someone else measures about you, you actually own. So, it's my hope, maybe because I'm a Canadian, that all of us can come together with this really valuable data that we've been storing, and we can collectively launch that data toward some of the world's most difficulty problems because big data can solve big problems, but I think it can do it the best if it's all of us who are in control. Thank you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Thorp's map of people saying good morning, who sleeps until later in the day?
Options: A. New York City, B. East Coast, C. West Coast, D. Midwest
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What initially charmed the speaker about Twitter? Options: A. The ability to share photos, B. The politeness of users saying "Good morning!", C. The character limit for tweets, D. The use of hashtags Correct Option: None
Question 2: What did the speaker create to visualize people saying "Good morning!" on Twitter? Options: A. A map showing the location of Twitter users, B. A graph showing the number of tweets per hour, C. A wave of people saying "Good morning!" across the world, D. A chart showing the most popular Twitter hashtags Correct Option: None
Question 3: What can be learned from the map showing people saying "Good morning!" on Twitter? Options: A. The most popular Twitter hashtags, B. The location of Twitter users, C. How people wake up in different parts of the world, D. The number of tweets per hour Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the purpose of the "Cascade" project? Options: A. To model how people move around the world, B. To model how people talk and have conversations, C. To study how disease is spread, D. To create a map of Twitter users Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the benefit of viewing conversations in three dimensions? Options: A. It is more visually appealing, B. It is easier to understand the scope of the conversation, C. It is more useful for humans who are used to three-dimensional structures, D. It is less interactive than two-dimensional views Correct Option: None
Question 6: What type of data is being referred to when the speaker says "we are data-making machines"? Options: A. Twitter data, B. Facebook data, C. Personal data that individuals produce, D. Company data Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who does the speaker suggest should be in control of personal data? Options: A. Companies, B. Governments, C. Individuals themselves, D. Scientists Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the speaker's hope for the collective use of personal data? Options: A. To solve small problems, B. To create more Twitter maps, C. To launch the data toward some of the world's most difficult problems, D. To store the data in companies Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the name of the project that models how people travel around the world? Options: A. Cascade, B. Good Morning, C. None (the project is not named), D. Twitter Travel Correct Option: None
Question 10: How can the data from Twitter be used to help scientists? Options: A. To study how people wake up in different parts of the world, B. To model how people talk and have conversations, C. To study how disease is spread, D. To create a map of Twitter users Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

Although Question 3 does not directly ask about who sleeps until later in the day, it does ask about what can be learned from the map showing people saying "Good morning!" on Twitter, and one of the options (C) is "How people wake up in different parts of the world." This is closely related to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about who sleeps until later in the day based on the map of people saying good morning.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. If I had to choose the most similar one, I would choose Question 3, but I would recommend generating new MCQs that more closely match the ground truth MCQ. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar A couple of years ago I started using Twitter, and one of the things that really charmed me about Twitter is that people would wake up in the morning and they would say, "Good morning!" which I thought, I'm a Canadian, so I was a little bit, I liked that politeness. And so, I'm also a giant nerd, and so I wrote a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!" And then I asked myself my favorite question, "What would that look like?" Well, as it turns out, I think it would look something like this. Right, so we'd see this wave of people saying, "Good morning!" across the world as they wake up. Now the green people, these are people that wake up at around 8 o'clock in the morning, Who wakes up at 8 o'clock or says, "Good morning!" at 8? And the orange people, they say, "Good morning!" around 9. And the red people, they say, "Good morning!" around 10. Yeah, more at 10's than, more at 10's than 8's. And actually if you look at this map, we can learn a little bit about how people wake up in different parts of the world. People on the West Coast, for example, they wake up a little bit later than those people on the East Coast. But that's not all that people say on Twitter, right? We also get these really important tweets, like, "I just landed in Orlando!! [plane sign, plane sign]" Or, or, "I just landed in Texas [exclamation point]!" Or "I just landed in Honduras!" These lists, they go on and on and on, all these people, right? So, on the outside, these people are just telling us something about how they're traveling. But we know the truth, don't we? These people are show-offs! They are showing off that they're in Cape Town and I'm not. So I thought, how can we take this vanity and turn it into utility? So using a similar approach that I did with "Good morning," I mapped all those people's trips because I know where they're landing, they just told me, and I know where they live because they share that information on their Twitter profile. So what I'm able to do with 36 hours of Twitter is create a model of how people are traveling around the world during that 36 hours. And this is kind of a prototype because I think if we listen to everybody on Twitter and Facebook and the rest of our social media, we'd actually get a pretty clear picture of how people are traveling from one place to the other, which is actually turns out to be a very useful thing for scientists, particularly those who are studying how disease is spread. So, I work upstairs in the New York Times, and for the last two years, we've been working on a project called, "Cascade," which in some ways is kind of similar to this one. But instead of modeling how people move, we're modeling how people talk. We're looking at what does a discussion look like. Well, here's an example. This is a discussion around an article called, "The Island Where People Forget to Die". It's about an island in Greece where people live a really, really, really, really, really, really long time. And what we're seeing here is we're seeing a conversation that's stemming from that first tweet down in the bottom, left-hand corner. So we get to see the scope of this conversation over about 9 hours right now, we're going to creep up to 12 hours here in a second. But, we can also see what that conversation looks like in three dimensions. And that three-dimensional view is actually much more useful for us. As humans, we are really used to things that are structured as three dimensions. So, we can look at those little off-shoots of conversation, we can find out what exactly happened. And this is an interactive, exploratory tool so we can go through every step in the conversation. We can look at who the people were, what they said, how old they are, where they live, who follows them, and so on, and so on, and so on. So, the Times creates about 6,500 pieces of content every month, and we can model every single one of the conversations that happen around them. And they look somewhat different. Depending on the story and depending on how fast people are talking about it and how far the conversation spreads, these structures, which I call these conversational architectures, end up looking different. So, these projects that I've shown you, I think they all involve the same thing: we can take small pieces of data and by putting them together, we can generate more value, we can do more exciting things with them. But so far we've only talked about Twitter, right? And Twitter isn't all the data. We learned a moment ago that there is tons and tons, tons more data out there. And specifically, I want you to think about one type of data because all of you guys, everybody in this audience, we, we, me as well, are data-making machines. We are producing data all the time. Every single one of us, we're producing data. Somebody else, though, is storing that data. Usually we put our trust into companies to store that data, but what I want to suggest here is that rather than putting our trust in companies to store that data, we should put the trust in ourselves because we actually own that data. Right, that is something we should remember. Everything that someone else measures about you, you actually own. So, it's my hope, maybe because I'm a Canadian, that all of us can come together with this really valuable data that we've been storing, and we can collectively launch that data toward some of the world's most difficulty problems because big data can solve big problems, but I think it can do it the best if it's all of us who are in control. Thank you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how much content does the New York Times create every month?
Options: A. 100 pieces, B. 1 million pieces, C. 6,500 pieces, D. 1,000 pieces
Correct Option: C

Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar A couple of years ago I started using Twitter, and one of the things that really charmed me about Twitter is that people would wake up in the morning and they would say, "Good morning!" which I thought, I'm a Canadian, so I was a little bit, I liked that politeness. And so, I'm also a giant nerd, and so I wrote a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!" And then I asked myself my favorite question, "What would that look like?" Well, as it turns out, I think it would look something like this. Right, so we'd see this wave of people saying, "Good morning!" across the world as they wake up. Now the green people, these are people that wake up at around 8 o'clock in the morning, Who wakes up at 8 o'clock or says, "Good morning!" at 8? And the orange people, they say, "Good morning!" around 9. And the red people, they say, "Good morning!" around 10. Yeah, more at 10's than, more at 10's than 8's. And actually if you look at this map, we can learn a little bit about how people wake up in different parts of the world. People on the West Coast, for example, they wake up a little bit later than those people on the East Coast. But that's not all that people say on Twitter, right? We also get these really important tweets, like, "I just landed in Orlando!! [plane sign, plane sign]" Or, or, "I just landed in Texas [exclamation point]!" Or "I just landed in Honduras!" These lists, they go on and on and on, all these people, right? So, on the outside, these people are just telling us something about how they're traveling. But we know the truth, don't we? These people are show-offs! They are showing off that they're in Cape Town and I'm not. So I thought, how can we take this vanity and turn it into utility? So using a similar approach that I did with "Good morning," I mapped all those people's trips because I know where they're landing, they just told me, and I know where they live because they share that information on their Twitter profile. So what I'm able to do with 36 hours of Twitter is create a model of how people are traveling around the world during that 36 hours. And this is kind of a prototype because I think if we listen to everybody on Twitter and Facebook and the rest of our social media, we'd actually get a pretty clear picture of how people are traveling from one place to the other, which is actually turns out to be a very useful thing for scientists, particularly those who are studying how disease is spread. So, I work upstairs in the New York Times, and for the last two years, we've been working on a project called, "Cascade," which in some ways is kind of similar to this one. But instead of modeling how people move, we're modeling how people talk. We're looking at what does a discussion look like. Well, here's an example. This is a discussion around an article called, "The Island Where People Forget to Die". It's about an island in Greece where people live a really, really, really, really, really, really long time. And what we're seeing here is we're seeing a conversation that's stemming from that first tweet down in the bottom, left-hand corner. So we get to see the scope of this conversation over about 9 hours right now, we're going to creep up to 12 hours here in a second. But, we can also see what that conversation looks like in three dimensions. And that three-dimensional view is actually much more useful for us. As humans, we are really used to things that are structured as three dimensions. So, we can look at those little off-shoots of conversation, we can find out what exactly happened. And this is an interactive, exploratory tool so we can go through every step in the conversation. We can look at who the people were, what they said, how old they are, where they live, who follows them, and so on, and so on, and so on. So, the Times creates about 6,500 pieces of content every month, and we can model every single one of the conversations that happen around them. And they look somewhat different. Depending on the story and depending on how fast people are talking about it and how far the conversation spreads, these structures, which I call these conversational architectures, end up looking different. So, these projects that I've shown you, I think they all involve the same thing: we can take small pieces of data and by putting them together, we can generate more value, we can do more exciting things with them. But so far we've only talked about Twitter, right? And Twitter isn't all the data. We learned a moment ago that there is tons and tons, tons more data out there. And specifically, I want you to think about one type of data because all of you guys, everybody in this audience, we, we, me as well, are data-making machines. We are producing data all the time. Every single one of us, we're producing data. Somebody else, though, is storing that data. Usually we put our trust into companies to store that data, but what I want to suggest here is that rather than putting our trust in companies to store that data, we should put the trust in ourselves because we actually own that data. Right, that is something we should remember. Everything that someone else measures about you, you actually own. So, it's my hope, maybe because I'm a Canadian, that all of us can come together with this really valuable data that we've been storing, and we can collectively launch that data toward some of the world's most difficulty problems because big data can solve big problems, but I think it can do it the best if it's all of us who are in control. Thank you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Thorp, you own data that's gathered:
Options: A. Anytime somebody measures something about you, B. When the government enlists you to be involved in a study, C. Only in a study that you conduct yourself, D. That doesn't include any information based on variables outside of yourself or your personal property
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Fourth and nineteen, folks, they've gotta have a play as time's ticking away because they've got to stay in this ball game, they've got to win. They come out lined up in the empty set, three receivers to the right, two to the left. Defense looks like they're gonna to man up with no safety. This is the exact offensive match-up that they want: the best receiver lined up against the linebacker. Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun. He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush. He's looking down field. He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. Quarterback has a beat on it. He lets the ball go, it's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender. He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen! He's at the ten, five! Touchdown! Unbelievable play! Now, wait a minute. Of course, it's believable, it's physics, specifically the differences between scalars and vectors. So, let's just see that replay. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Stop. See, measurements are defined as two different quantities. Scalars are measurements with only numbers, and vectors are measurements with direction. For example, when that quarterback takes the snap, he's five yards away, but from where? Back from the line of scrimmage, so the five yards by itself is a scalar quantity. When you add a direction, like five yards deep, it becomes a vector quantity. Five yards - scalar, five yards deep - vector. OK, go ahead. "He takes a snap, drops three steps. He plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Whoa! Here's a difference between distance and displacement. Distance is a measurement without identifying where you moved. It's a scalar quantity. When the quarterback makes a three-step drop, he moves about three yards back. When he moves about another three yards forward, when he steps up into the pocket, so that quarterback moves a total distance of six yards. That's a distance, that's a scalar. Now, displacement is a vector quantity, describing about how far out of place the object is. So the quarterback dropped back three yards and then moved back forward three yards, he's in the exact same place where he started. So, his displacement is zero yards. Distance - six yards, displacement - zero yards. So, let's look at what happened next. "Quarterback has a beat on it, he let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender." Stop. So, here's speed and velocity, but let's just do one thing at a time. So, speed is measurement without direction, it's a scalar quantity. Velocity is a vector quantity. It is that object's speed, but with a direction of motion. So the receiver accelerates away, gaining both speed and distance. This takes the receiver 5 seconds to run those 50 yards. So his average speed, in any given time, is 10 yards/second. The linebacker tries to keep up, but his overall speed is slower, he only goes 35 yards in those 5 seconds, so his average speed is only 7 yards/second. They're both traveling in a forward direction, so their velocity is also positive. You can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately. You've got to build up to it. This is acceleration. At first the linebacker can keep up with that receiver, but eventually the faster receiver pulls away. That's acceleration, the change in speed over time. Acceleration is a vector quantity. It describes a rate at which an object changes velocity. Like velocity, acceleration is a vector. It happens in a direction. So let's just look at that play just one more time. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Vector! "He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot. He's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Displacement! "He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. The quarterback has a beat on it. He let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender!" Velocity! "He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen, he's at the ten, five!" Acceleration! "Touchdown! Unbelievable play! That was a great play as time expired, resulting in the touchdown and ultimately the win and pure effort." And pure science.

Back from the line of scrimmage, so the five yards by itself is a scalar quantity. When you add a direction, like five yards deep, it becomes a vector quantity. Five yards - scalar, five yards deep - vector. OK, go ahead. "He takes a snap, drops three steps. He plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! When he moves about another three yards forward, when he steps up into the pocket, so that quarterback moves a total distance of six yards. That's a distance, that's a scalar. Now, displacement is a vector quantity, describing about how far out of place the object is. So the quarterback dropped back three yards and then moved back forward three yards, he's in the exact same place where he started. So, his displacement is zero yards. Stop. So, here's speed and velocity, but let's just do one thing at a time. So, speed is measurement without direction, it's a scalar quantity. Velocity is a vector quantity. It is that object's speed, but with a direction of motion. So the receiver accelerates away, gaining both speed and distance. This takes the receiver 5 seconds to run those 50 yards. So his average speed, in any given time, is 10 yards/second. The linebacker tries to keep up, but his overall speed is slower, he only goes 35 yards in those 5 seconds, so his average speed is only 7 yards/second. They're both traveling in a forward direction, so their velocity is also positive. You can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately. You've got to build up to it. This is acceleration. At first the linebacker can keep up with that receiver, but eventually the faster receiver pulls away. That's acceleration, the change in speed over time. Acceleration is a vector quantity. He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush. He's looking down field. He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. Quarterback has a beat on it. He lets the ball go, it's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender. He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen! He's at the ten, five! Touchdown! Unbelievable play! Now, wait a minute. Of course, it's believable, it's physics, specifically the differences between scalars and vectors. So, let's just see that replay. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Stop. See, measurements are defined as two different quantities. Scalars are measurements with only numbers, and vectors are measurements with direction. For example, when that quarterback takes the snap, he's five yards away, but from where? Back from the line of scrimmage, so the five yards by itself is a scalar quantity. When you add a direction, like five yards deep, it becomes a vector quantity. Five yards - scalar, five yards deep - vector. OK, go ahead. "He takes a snap, drops three steps. He plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Whoa! Here's a difference between distance and displacement. Distance is a measurement without identifying where you moved. It's a scalar quantity. When the quarterback makes a three-step drop, he moves about three yards back. When he moves about another three yards forward, when he steps up into the pocket, so that quarterback moves a total distance of six yards. That's a distance, that's a scalar. Now, displacement is a vector quantity, describing about how far out of place the object is. So the quarterback dropped back three yards and then moved back forward three yards, he's in the exact same place where he started. So, his displacement is zero yards. Distance - six yards, displacement - zero yards. So, let's look at what happened next. "Quarterback has a beat on it, he let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender." Stop. So, here's speed and velocity, but let's just do one thing at a time. So, speed is measurement without direction, it's a scalar quantity. Velocity is a vector quantity. It is that object's speed, but with a direction of motion. So the receiver accelerates away, gaining both speed and distance. This takes the receiver 5 seconds to run those 50 yards. So his average speed, in any given time, is 10 yards/second. The linebacker tries to keep up, but his overall speed is slower, he only goes 35 yards in those 5 seconds, so his average speed is only 7 yards/second. They're both traveling in a forward direction, so their velocity is also positive. You can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately. You've got to build up to it. This is acceleration. At first the linebacker can keep up with that receiver, but eventually the faster receiver pulls away. That's acceleration, the change in speed over time. Acceleration is a vector quantity. It describes a rate at which an object changes velocity. Like velocity, acceleration is a vector. It happens in a direction. So let's just look at that play just one more time. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Vector! "He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot. He's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Displacement! "He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. The quarterback has a beat on it. He let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender!" Velocity! "He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen, he's at the ten, five!" Acceleration! "Touchdown! Unbelievable play! That was a great play as time expired, resulting in the touchdown and ultimately the win and pure effort." And pure science.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What principle describes why you can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately?
Options: A. Velocity, B. Displacement, C. Trajectory, D. Acceleration
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary difference between a scalar and a vector quantity? Options: A. A scalar has direction, while a vector does not., B. A scalar has magnitude, while a vector does not., C. A scalar has only magnitude, while a vector has both magnitude and direction., D. A scalar has only direction, while a vector has both magnitude and direction. Correct Option: None
Question 2: In the example given, what is the scalar quantity mentioned when the quarterback takes the snap? Options: A. Five yards deep, B. Five yards, C. Three steps, D. Three yards Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the vector quantity describing how far out of place an object is? Options: A. Distance, B. Displacement, C. Speed, D. Velocity Correct Option: None
Question 4: In the example given, what is the quarterback's displacement after dropping back three yards and then moving forward three yards? Options: A. 3 yards, B. 6 yards, C. 0 yards, D. -3 yards Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the primary difference between speed and velocity? Options: A. Speed is a vector quantity, while velocity is a scalar quantity., B. Speed is a scalar quantity, while velocity is a vector quantity., C. Speed is a measure of distance, while velocity is a measure of displacement., D. Speed is a measure of time, while velocity is a measure of direction. Correct Option: None
Question 6: In the example given, what is the receiver's average speed over 5 seconds? Options: A. 5 yards/second, B. 7 yards/second, C. 10 yards/second, D. 15 yards/second Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is acceleration, as described in the transcript? Options: A. A change in speed over time, B. A change in direction over time, C. A change in velocity over time, D. A change in displacement over time Correct Option: None

The linebacker keeps up with the receiver., C. The linebacker slows down., D. The linebacker is eventually left behind by the faster receiver. Correct Option: None

A field goal is scored, resulting in a tie., C. A touchdown is scored, but the game is lost., D. A field goal is scored, resulting in a win. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Ever see a medieval painting of baby Jesus sitting or standing on his mother's lap and wonder why she's so large? Paintings like Cimabue's enthroned Madonna with angels or Duccio's Maesta also appear out of proportion. If Mary were to stand up, it seems, the angels in the picture would be as tall as her shin bone, and her torso would be disproportionately small when compared to her legs. Maybe you thought the artist simply wasn't skilled enough to paint realistically or lacked the mathematical skill of perspective. But that's not the full story. To understand why, we need to go back to the late fifth century when the city of Rome was attacked by the Goths. Rome was built in marble and meant to last forever. It represented, for many years, the pinnacle of human civilization, so its destruction left a huge void. Theologians, who preached about a world beyond the physical, began attracting an audience as Rome crumbled, and Christianity started to fill the void left by the Empire. As a replacement for the physical beauty of Rome, Christianity offered a metaphysical beauty of virtue and an eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had. After the fall of Rome, early medieval theologians turned away from physical beauty, rejecting it in favor of inner-beauty. They maintained that while the physical world was temporary, virtue and religion were permanent. Beautiful objects could lead to a misguided worship of the object rather than the worship of goodness. It is said that the early sixth century preacher, St. Benedict, upon thinking of a beautiful woman, threw himself into a thorn patch, and through his suffering, regained his focus on spiritual beauty. He feared his desire for the beautiful woman would distract him from his desire to love God. As European civilization transitioned away from empires and towards religion, monasteries became the gatekeepers of knowledge, which meant that classical books that praised physical pleasures were not copied or protected. Without protection, they became the victims of natural decay, fire, flooding, or pests. And without the help of monks transcribing new copies, these texts and the philosophies they carried disappeared in Western Europe and were replaced by the works of people like St. Benedict, which brings us back to these depictions of Jesus and Mary. Because Christianity had so fervently rejected physical beauty, these medieval artists purposefully avoided aesthetically pleasing forms. At first, decorations for churches or palaces were limited to interesting geometric patterns, which could be pleasing without inspiring sinful thoughts of physical pleasure. As the medieval period progressed, depictions of Jesus and Mary were tolerated, but the artist clearly made an effort to veil Mary and give her disproportionately large legs, with those enormous shin bones. The fear remained that a beautiful illustration of Mary might inspire the viewer to love the painting or the physical form of Mary, rather than the virtue she's meant to represent. So even though it may be fun to think we can paint more realistically than Cimabuey or Duccio, we need to remember that they had different goals when picking up a paintbrush.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What prominent figure in Medieval paintings was commonly painted out of proportion?
Options: A. Mary, the mother of Jesus, B. David, the shepherd boy, C. Gabriel, the angel, D. Venus, the Roman goddess
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who painted the "Enthroned Madonna with Angels"? Options: A. Duccio, B. Cimabue, C. St. Benedict, D. Leonardo da Vinci Correct Option: None
Question 2: Why did early medieval theologians reject physical beauty? Options: A. They believed it was too expensive to maintain., B. They thought it was a distraction from spiritual beauty and virtue., C. They did not have the skills to create beautiful objects., D. They believed it was a sin to create art. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What event in the late fifth century led to a shift in focus from physical beauty to spiritual beauty? Options: A. The construction of a new church in Rome, B. The attack on Rome by the Goths, C. The discovery of a new art technique, D. The birth of a new emperor Correct Option: None
Question 4: Why did St. Benedict throw himself into a thorn patch? Options: A. He was trying to punish himself for a sin., B. He wanted to prove his devotion to God., C. He was distracted by thoughts of a beautiful woman and wanted to regain his focus on spiritual beauty., D. He was trying to escape from his enemies. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happened to classical books that praised physical pleasures during the transition from empires to religion in Europe? Options: A. They were widely copied and distributed., B. They were protected by the monasteries., C. They were not copied or protected and eventually disappeared., D. They were translated into new languages. Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why did medieval artists purposefully avoid aesthetically pleasing forms in their depictions of Jesus and Mary? Options: A. They lacked the skills to create realistic art., B. They wanted to focus on the spiritual beauty of the subjects., C. They were trying to create a new art style., D. They were following the instructions of the church. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What type of decorations were initially allowed in churches and palaces during the medieval period? Options: A. Depictions of Jesus and Mary, B. Interesting geometric patterns, C. Scenes from classical mythology, D. Portraits of monarchs Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why did medieval artists depict Mary with disproportionately large legs and shin bones? Options: A. They wanted to emphasize her physical strength., B. They were trying to create a realistic representation of the human body., C. They wanted to veil her physical beauty and prevent the viewer from being distracted from her virtue., D. They were following a new art trend. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the main goal of medieval artists when depicting Jesus and Mary? Options: A. To create a realistic representation of the subjects, B. To showcase their artistic skills, C. To convey the spiritual beauty and virtue of the subjects, D. To decorate the churches and palaces Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it important to consider the historical context when evaluating the art of medieval artists like Cimabue and Duccio? Options: A. Because they were not skilled enough to create realistic art., B. Because they were trying to create a new art style., C. Because they had different goals and values than modern artists., D. Because they were following the instructions of the church. Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

Although the question is phrased differently, the intent and content of Question 8 align with the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks about the prominent figure in Medieval paintings that was commonly painted out of proportion, and Question 8 asks about the reason behind the depiction of Mary with disproportionately large legs and shin bones. 

However, a more direct match in terms of question content would be beneficial. Among the provided options, Question 8 is the closest match, but it does not perfectly align with the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would choose Question 8 as the most similar generated MCQ, with the understanding that a more direct match would be ideal.

Index: 8

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Ever see a medieval painting of baby Jesus sitting or standing on his mother's lap and wonder why she's so large? Paintings like Cimabue's enthroned Madonna with angels or Duccio's Maesta also appear out of proportion. If Mary were to stand up, it seems, the angels in the picture would be as tall as her shin bone, and her torso would be disproportionately small when compared to her legs. Maybe you thought the artist simply wasn't skilled enough to paint realistically or lacked the mathematical skill of perspective. But that's not the full story. To understand why, we need to go back to the late fifth century when the city of Rome was attacked by the Goths. Rome was built in marble and meant to last forever. It represented, for many years, the pinnacle of human civilization, so its destruction left a huge void. Theologians, who preached about a world beyond the physical, began attracting an audience as Rome crumbled, and Christianity started to fill the void left by the Empire. As a replacement for the physical beauty of Rome, Christianity offered a metaphysical beauty of virtue and an eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had. After the fall of Rome, early medieval theologians turned away from physical beauty, rejecting it in favor of inner-beauty. They maintained that while the physical world was temporary, virtue and religion were permanent. Beautiful objects could lead to a misguided worship of the object rather than the worship of goodness. It is said that the early sixth century preacher, St. Benedict, upon thinking of a beautiful woman, threw himself into a thorn patch, and through his suffering, regained his focus on spiritual beauty. He feared his desire for the beautiful woman would distract him from his desire to love God. As European civilization transitioned away from empires and towards religion, monasteries became the gatekeepers of knowledge, which meant that classical books that praised physical pleasures were not copied or protected. Without protection, they became the victims of natural decay, fire, flooding, or pests. And without the help of monks transcribing new copies, these texts and the philosophies they carried disappeared in Western Europe and were replaced by the works of people like St. Benedict, which brings us back to these depictions of Jesus and Mary. Because Christianity had so fervently rejected physical beauty, these medieval artists purposefully avoided aesthetically pleasing forms. At first, decorations for churches or palaces were limited to interesting geometric patterns, which could be pleasing without inspiring sinful thoughts of physical pleasure. As the medieval period progressed, depictions of Jesus and Mary were tolerated, but the artist clearly made an effort to veil Mary and give her disproportionately large legs, with those enormous shin bones. The fear remained that a beautiful illustration of Mary might inspire the viewer to love the painting or the physical form of Mary, rather than the virtue she's meant to represent. So even though it may be fun to think we can paint more realistically than Cimabuey or Duccio, we need to remember that they had different goals when picking up a paintbrush.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did Christianity offer in place of the crumbling Roman empire?
Options: A. A metaphysical beauty of virtue, B. An eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had, C. Protection from invading countries, D. Both A and B
Correct Option: D

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What first populated art spaces in churches and palaces after the fall of Rome?
Options: A. Solid colors that represented the deadly sins and the holy virtues, B. Country landscapes that reminded parishioners of peace, C. Interesting geometric patterns that lacked a semblance of physical beauty, D. Depictions of stories from scripture, especially those from the first five books of the Bible
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who painted the "Enthroned Madonna with Angels"? Options: A. Duccio, B. Cimabue, C. St. Benedict, D. Leonardo da Vinci Correct Option: None

They thought it was a distraction from spiritual beauty and virtue., C. They did not have the skills to create beautiful objects., D. They believed it was a sin to create art. Correct Option: None

They wanted to focus on the spiritual beauty of the subjects., C. They were trying to create a new art style., D. They were following the instructions of the church. Correct Option: None

They were following a new art trend. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Ever see a medieval painting of baby Jesus sitting or standing on his mother's lap and wonder why she's so large? Paintings like Cimabue's enthroned Madonna with angels or Duccio's Maesta also appear out of proportion. If Mary were to stand up, it seems, the angels in the picture would be as tall as her shin bone, and her torso would be disproportionately small when compared to her legs. Maybe you thought the artist simply wasn't skilled enough to paint realistically or lacked the mathematical skill of perspective. But that's not the full story. To understand why, we need to go back to the late fifth century when the city of Rome was attacked by the Goths. Rome was built in marble and meant to last forever. It represented, for many years, the pinnacle of human civilization, so its destruction left a huge void. Theologians, who preached about a world beyond the physical, began attracting an audience as Rome crumbled, and Christianity started to fill the void left by the Empire. As a replacement for the physical beauty of Rome, Christianity offered a metaphysical beauty of virtue and an eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had. After the fall of Rome, early medieval theologians turned away from physical beauty, rejecting it in favor of inner-beauty. They maintained that while the physical world was temporary, virtue and religion were permanent. Beautiful objects could lead to a misguided worship of the object rather than the worship of goodness. It is said that the early sixth century preacher, St. Benedict, upon thinking of a beautiful woman, threw himself into a thorn patch, and through his suffering, regained his focus on spiritual beauty. He feared his desire for the beautiful woman would distract him from his desire to love God. As European civilization transitioned away from empires and towards religion, monasteries became the gatekeepers of knowledge, which meant that classical books that praised physical pleasures were not copied or protected. Without protection, they became the victims of natural decay, fire, flooding, or pests. And without the help of monks transcribing new copies, these texts and the philosophies they carried disappeared in Western Europe and were replaced by the works of people like St. Benedict, which brings us back to these depictions of Jesus and Mary. Because Christianity had so fervently rejected physical beauty, these medieval artists purposefully avoided aesthetically pleasing forms. At first, decorations for churches or palaces were limited to interesting geometric patterns, which could be pleasing without inspiring sinful thoughts of physical pleasure. As the medieval period progressed, depictions of Jesus and Mary were tolerated, but the artist clearly made an effort to veil Mary and give her disproportionately large legs, with those enormous shin bones. The fear remained that a beautiful illustration of Mary might inspire the viewer to love the painting or the physical form of Mary, rather than the virtue she's meant to represent. So even though it may be fun to think we can paint more realistically than Cimabuey or Duccio, we need to remember that they had different goals when picking up a paintbrush.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What's the best reason (or the best reasons) Cimabue and Duccio painted a veiled, disproportionate Mary?
Options: A. They had a different goal in mind when painting, B. They didn't want to tempt people to worship the painting instead of the virtue it represented, C. They realized that Mary was not entirely mortal, as she was chosen by God, therefore must be represented differently in paintings, D. Both A and B
Correct Option: D

Question 4: Why did St. Benedict throw himself into a thorn patch? Options: A. He was trying to punish himself for a sin., B. He wanted to prove his devotion to God., C. They were trying to create a realistic representation of the human body., C. They wanted to veil her physical beauty and prevent the viewer from being distracted from her virtue., D. They were following a new art trend. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the main goal of medieval artists when depicting Jesus and Mary? Options: A. To create a realistic representation of the subjects, B. To showcase their artistic skills, C. Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

Although the options do not exactly match, the intent and content of the question align with the ground truth MCQ. Question 8 asks about the specific artistic choice of depicting Mary with disproportionately large legs and shin bones, which is related to the ground truth MCQ's inquiry about the reason behind Cimabue and Duccio's depiction of a veiled, disproportionate Mary.

However, another question that closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6, as it inquires about the general reason behind medieval artists' avoidance of aesthetically pleasing forms in their depictions of Jesus and Mary.

But if we were to choose one, Question 8 would be the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The Oval Office, Inauguration Day, Rose Garden signings, and secret service agents with dark sunglasses and cool wrist radios. For a moment, forget all of it. Toss out everything you know about the President. Now, start over. What would you do if you had to invent the President? That was the question facing the 55 men who got together in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia, in the same place where the Declaration of Independence had been written eleven years earlier. Declaring independence had been risky business, demanding ferocious courage that put lives and fortunes in jeopardy. But, inventing a new government was no field day either, especially when it's summer and you're in scratchy suits, and the windows are closed because you don't want anybody to hear what you are saying, and the air conditioning doesn't work because it won't be invented for nearly 200 years. And, when you don't agree on things, it gets even hotter. For the framers, the question they argued over most while writing the Constitution and creating three branches of government had to do with the executive department. One man or three to do the job? How long should he serve? What would he really do? Who would pick him? How to get rid of him if he's doing a bad job or he's a crook? And, of course, they all meant him, and he would be a white man. The idea of a woman or an African American, for instance, holding this high office was not a glimmer in their eyes. But the framers knew they needed someone who could take charge, especially in a crisis, like an invasion or a rebellion, or negotiating treaties. Congress was not very good at making such important decisions without debates and delays. But the framers thought America needed a man who was decisive and could act quickly. They called it energy and dispatch. One thing they were dead-set against: there would be no king. They had fought a war against a country with a monarch and were afraid that one man with unchecked powers, in charge of an army, could take over the country. Instead, they settled on a president and laid out his powers in Article 2 of the Constitution. But who would choose him? Not the people, they were too liable to be misled as one framer worried. Not the legislature, that would lead to cabal and factions. Got it: electors, wise, informed men who have time to make a good decision. And if they didn't produce a winner, then the decision would go to one of the other branches of government, the Congress. The House of Representatives would step in and make the choice, which they did in 1801 and 1825. In the long, hot summer of 1787, compromises were made to invent the presidency, like counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, giving the President command of the army but Congress the power to declare war, and unlimited four-year terms. Since then, some of those compromises have been amended and the men in office have sometimes been too strong or too weak. But, if you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where and when was the Constitution written?
Options: A. Philadelphia - 1787, B. Washington D.C. - 1800, C. New York - 1796, D. Boston - 1776
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where did the 55 men gather in secret to draw up plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787? Options: A. New York City, B. Philadelphia, C. Boston, D. Washington D.C. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the primary concern of the framers when creating the executive department of the government? Options: A. How to divide power among the three branches, B. How to ensure the president had absolute power, C. How to design the role and responsibilities of the president, D. How to establish a monarch-like system Correct Option: None
Question 3: According to the transcript, why did the framers decide against having Congress choose the president? Options: A. They wanted the people to have direct control, B. They worried it would lead to cabal and factions, C. They thought it would be too time-consuming, D. They believed Congress was too inexperienced Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the primary reason the framers decided to create the office of the president? Options: A. To have a figurehead for the government, B. To provide a check on the power of Congress, C. To have a leader who could take charge in times of crisis, D. To establish a monarch-like system Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the term used by the framers to describe the qualities they wanted in a president? Options: A. Energy and dispatch, B. Strength and courage, C. Wisdom and compassion, D. Honesty and integrity Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the transcript, what was one of the compromises made during the summer of 1787? Options: A. Counting slaves as full citizens, B. Giving the president absolute power, C. Counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, D. Limiting the president's term to two years Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who would choose the president if the electors did not produce a winner? Options: A. The Senate, B. The House of Representatives, C. The Supreme Court, D. The people Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the primary concern of the framers regarding the power of the president? Options: A. That they would be too weak, B. That they would be too strong and take over the country, C. That they would be too influenced by Congress, D. That they would be too focused on foreign policy Correct Option: None
Question 9: According to the transcript, what was the reason for the framers' decision to have electors choose the president? Options: A. They wanted to give the people direct control, B. They believed electors would be wise and informed, C. They wanted to limit the power of Congress, D. They thought it would be more efficient Correct Option: None
Question 10: In what years did the House of Representatives step in to choose the president due to the electors not producing a winner? Options: A. 1801 and 1820, B. 1801 and 1825, C. 1820 and 1825, D. 1800 and 1810 Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the options and the phrasing of the question are not identical, the intent and content of Question 1 are closest to the ground truth MCQ. Both questions ask about the location (and, in the case of the ground truth MCQ, the year) where the plans for a new American government were drawn up. 

However, it's worth noting that the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ includes the year "1787", which is mentioned in the transcript as the year when the 55 men gathered in secret. Question 1 does not include the year in its options, but the transcript does mention that the event occurred in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The Oval Office, Inauguration Day, Rose Garden signings, and secret service agents with dark sunglasses and cool wrist radios. For a moment, forget all of it. Toss out everything you know about the President. Now, start over. What would you do if you had to invent the President? That was the question facing the 55 men who got together in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia, in the same place where the Declaration of Independence had been written eleven years earlier. Declaring independence had been risky business, demanding ferocious courage that put lives and fortunes in jeopardy. But, inventing a new government was no field day either, especially when it's summer and you're in scratchy suits, and the windows are closed because you don't want anybody to hear what you are saying, and the air conditioning doesn't work because it won't be invented for nearly 200 years. And, when you don't agree on things, it gets even hotter. For the framers, the question they argued over most while writing the Constitution and creating three branches of government had to do with the executive department. One man or three to do the job? How long should he serve? What would he really do? Who would pick him? How to get rid of him if he's doing a bad job or he's a crook? And, of course, they all meant him, and he would be a white man. The idea of a woman or an African American, for instance, holding this high office was not a glimmer in their eyes. But the framers knew they needed someone who could take charge, especially in a crisis, like an invasion or a rebellion, or negotiating treaties. Congress was not very good at making such important decisions without debates and delays. But the framers thought America needed a man who was decisive and could act quickly. They called it energy and dispatch. One thing they were dead-set against: there would be no king. They had fought a war against a country with a monarch and were afraid that one man with unchecked powers, in charge of an army, could take over the country. Instead, they settled on a president and laid out his powers in Article 2 of the Constitution. But who would choose him? Not the people, they were too liable to be misled as one framer worried. Not the legislature, that would lead to cabal and factions. Got it: electors, wise, informed men who have time to make a good decision. And if they didn't produce a winner, then the decision would go to one of the other branches of government, the Congress. The House of Representatives would step in and make the choice, which they did in 1801 and 1825. In the long, hot summer of 1787, compromises were made to invent the presidency, like counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, giving the President command of the army but Congress the power to declare war, and unlimited four-year terms. Since then, some of those compromises have been amended and the men in office have sometimes been too strong or too weak. But, if you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to the narrator, the men who wrote the Constitution were afraid of:
Options: A. Texas, B. Indians, C. Foreigners, D. An American king
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where did the 55 men gather in secret to draw up plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787? Options: A. New York City, B. Philadelphia, C. Boston, D. Washington D.C. Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the primary concern of the framers when creating the executive department of the government? Options: A. How to divide power among the three branches, B. How to ensure the president had absolute power, C. How to design the role and responsibilities of the president, D. How to establish a monarch-like system Correct Option: None
Question 3: According to the transcript, why did the framers decide against having Congress choose the president? Options: A. They wanted the people to have direct control, B. They worried it would lead to cabal and factions, C. They thought it would be too time-consuming, D. They believed Congress was too inexperienced Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the primary reason the framers decided to create the office of the president? Options: A. To have a figurehead for the government, B. To provide a check on the power of Congress, C. To have a leader who could take charge in times of crisis, D. To establish a monarch-like system Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the term used by the framers to describe the qualities they wanted in a president? Options: A. Energy and dispatch, B. Strength and courage, C. Wisdom and compassion, D. Honesty and integrity Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the transcript, what was one of the compromises made during the summer of 1787? Options: A. Counting slaves as full citizens, B. Giving the president absolute power, C. Counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, D. Limiting the president's term to two years Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who would choose the president if the electors did not produce a winner? Options: A. The Senate, B. The House of Representatives, C. The Supreme Court, D. The people Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the primary concern of the framers regarding the power of the president? Options: A. That they would be too weak, B. That they would be too strong and take over the country, C. That they would be too influenced by Congress, D. That they would be too focused on foreign policy Correct Option: None
Question 9: According to the transcript, what was the reason for the framers' decision to have electors choose the president? Options: A. They wanted to give the people direct control, B. They believed electors would be wise and informed, C. They wanted to limit the power of Congress, D. They thought it would be more efficient Correct Option: None
Question 10: In what years did the House of Representatives step in to choose the president due to the electors not producing a winner? Options: A. 1801 and 1820, B. 1801 and 1825, C. 1820 and 1825, D. 1800 and 1810 Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question aligns with the intent and content of the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the fear of the men who wrote the Constitution. The correct option in Question 8 (B. That they would be too strong and take over the country) is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (D. An American king), as both refer to the concern about a single person having too much power. 

Although the wording is not identical, the overall intent and meaning of Question 8 are closest to the ground truth MCQ among the provided options.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The Oval Office, Inauguration Day, Rose Garden signings, and secret service agents with dark sunglasses and cool wrist radios. For a moment, forget all of it. Toss out everything you know about the President. Now, start over. What would you do if you had to invent the President? That was the question facing the 55 men who got together in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia, in the same place where the Declaration of Independence had been written eleven years earlier. Declaring independence had been risky business, demanding ferocious courage that put lives and fortunes in jeopardy. But, inventing a new government was no field day either, especially when it's summer and you're in scratchy suits, and the windows are closed because you don't want anybody to hear what you are saying, and the air conditioning doesn't work because it won't be invented for nearly 200 years. And, when you don't agree on things, it gets even hotter. For the framers, the question they argued over most while writing the Constitution and creating three branches of government had to do with the executive department. One man or three to do the job? How long should he serve? What would he really do? Who would pick him? How to get rid of him if he's doing a bad job or he's a crook? And, of course, they all meant him, and he would be a white man. The idea of a woman or an African American, for instance, holding this high office was not a glimmer in their eyes. But the framers knew they needed someone who could take charge, especially in a crisis, like an invasion or a rebellion, or negotiating treaties. Congress was not very good at making such important decisions without debates and delays. But the framers thought America needed a man who was decisive and could act quickly. They called it energy and dispatch. One thing they were dead-set against: there would be no king. They had fought a war against a country with a monarch and were afraid that one man with unchecked powers, in charge of an army, could take over the country. Instead, they settled on a president and laid out his powers in Article 2 of the Constitution. But who would choose him? Not the people, they were too liable to be misled as one framer worried. Not the legislature, that would lead to cabal and factions. Got it: electors, wise, informed men who have time to make a good decision. And if they didn't produce a winner, then the decision would go to one of the other branches of government, the Congress. The House of Representatives would step in and make the choice, which they did in 1801 and 1825. In the long, hot summer of 1787, compromises were made to invent the presidency, like counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, giving the President command of the army but Congress the power to declare war, and unlimited four-year terms. Since then, some of those compromises have been amended and the men in office have sometimes been too strong or too weak. But, if you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office?

Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
so basically we have public leaders public officials who are out of control they're writing bills that are unintelligible and out of these bills are going to come maybe 40,000 pages of regulations total complexity which has a dramatically negative impact on our life if you're a veteran coming back from Iraq or Vietnam you face a blizzard of paperwork to get your benefits if you're trying to get a small business loan you face a blizzard of paperwork what are we going to do about it i define simplicity as a means to achieving clarity transparency and empathy building humanity into communications I've been simplifying things for 30 years I come over the out of the advertising and design business my focus is understanding you people and how you interact with the government to get your benefits how you interact with corporations decide who you're going to do business with and how you view brands so very quickly when President Obama said I don't see why we can't have a one-page plain English consumer credit agreement so I locked myself in a room figured out the content organize the document and wrote it in plain English I've had this checked by the two top consumer credit lawyers in the country this is a real thing now I want one step further and said why do we have to stick with the stodgy lawyers and just have a paper document let's go online so many people might need help in computation working with the Harvard Business School you'll see this example when you talk about minimum payments if you spend sixty two dollars for a meal the longer you take to pay out that loan you see over a period of time using the minimum payment it's 99 dollars and 17 cents how about that you think your bank is going to show that to people but it's going to work it's more effective than just computational aids and what about terms like over the limit perhaps a stealth thing to find it in context tell people what it means when you put it in plain English you almost force the institution to give the people away i default out of that and not put themselves at risk plain english is about changing the content and one of the things I'm most proud of is this agreement for IBM it's a grid its calendar at such-and-such a date IBM F responsibilities you have responsibilities received very favorably by by business and there's some good news to report today each year one in ten taxpayers receive a notice from the IRS there are 200 million letters that go out running through this typical letter that they had I ran it through my simplicity lab it's pretty unintelligible all the parts of the document in red are not intelligible we looked at doing over a thousand letters that cover 70% of the transactions they're in plain English they've been tested in the laboratory when I run it through my lab this heat mapping shows everything is intelligible and the IRS has introduced the program looking at there's one there are a couple of things going on right now that I want to bring to your attention there's a lot of discussion now about consumer financial protection agency how to mandate simplicity we see all this complexity it's incumbent upon us and this organization I believe to make clarity transparency and empathy a national priority there is no way that we should allow government to communicate the way they communicate there is no way we should do business with companies that have agreements with stealth provisions and that aren't intelligible so how are we going to change the world make clarity transparency and simplicity a national priority what does a machine know about itself can it know when it needs to be repaired and when it doesn't in industries like manufacturing and energy they're using predictive analytics to detect signs of trouble helping some companies save millions on maintenance because machines seek help before they're broken and don't when they're not that's what I'm working on I'm an IBM er let's build a smarter planet
